intro: Taraxacum pilicatum, commonly known as the hairy dandelion, is a species of flowering plant in the family Asteraceae. It is characterized by its distinctive yellow composite flowers and heart-shaped basal leaves covered in fine, hairy glands. The plant is native to eastern North America and thrives in moist, disturbed soils such as those found in meadows and along roadsides. It produces a hollow, wind-dispersed seed stem known as a pappus, which aids in its reproductive success. The hairy dandelion is often considered a weed but also serves as a food source for various insects and a symbol of resilience in natural ecosystems.
